FAQ & Resources

Common questions about electrical services, safety advice, and useful resources for homeowners and landlords in Somerset.

Electrical Emergency?

If you experience any of these issues, turn off the main power and call immediately:

  • • Burning smells from electrical equipment
  • • Sparks or electrical arcing
  • • Electric shocks from appliances
  • • Complete power loss with no obvious cause
Emergency: 07464 336661

General Questions

How quickly can you respond to emergencies?

We aim to respond to electrical emergencies within 2 hours across our Somerset service area. For same-day non-emergency work, we typically respond within 4-6 hours. Planned work is usually scheduled for the next working day.

What areas do you cover?

We're based in Shepton Mallet and serve all of Somerset including Taunton, Yeovil, Bridgwater, Frome, Wells, Glastonbury and surrounding areas. Contact us to confirm coverage for your specific location.

Do you provide written quotes?

Yes, all quotes are provided in writing with transparent pricing. We believe in no hidden costs and will explain exactly what work is required and why.

Are you insured and qualified?

Yes, we're fully qualified (18th Edition City & Guilds), NAPIT registered, TrustMark registered, and carry full public liability insurance. DBS checks available on request.

EICR Testing

How often do landlords need an EICR?

Private rental properties must have a valid EICR renewed every 5 years, or upon change of tenancy if more than 5 years old. This is a legal requirement under The Electrical Safety Standards in the Private Rented Sector (England) Regulations 2020.

How long does an EICR take?

Typically 2-4 hours for an average home, depending on size and complexity. Larger properties or those with complex electrical systems may take longer. We provide same-day certificates when possible.

What happens if my EICR fails?

We'll provide a detailed report of any issues found. Many problems can be fixed on the same visit, allowing for immediate re-certification. We'll explain all issues in plain English and provide cost estimates for any required work.

Consumer Units

When should I upgrade my consumer unit?

Consider upgrading if you have an old fuse box with wire fuses, no RCD protection, frequent tripping, or a unit over 15 years old. Modern consumer units with RCBOs provide much better protection.

What's the difference between RCDs and RCBOs?

RCDs protect multiple circuits, while RCBOs provide individual protection per circuit. With RCBOs, if one circuit has a fault, only that circuit trips - not your entire home. This provides better convenience and safety.

How long will I be without power during an upgrade?

Most consumer unit upgrades are completed in 4-6 hours. We work efficiently to minimize disruption and restore power as quickly as possible, usually the same day.

Electrical Safety

What should I do if my RCD keeps tripping?

Don't ignore it! First, unplug all appliances and try resetting. If it stays on, plug appliances back in one at a time to identify the faulty item. If it trips with nothing connected, call an electrician immediately as this indicates a wiring fault.

Can I do electrical work myself?

Some basic work like changing light bulbs and replacing like-for-like accessories is allowed. However, most electrical work requires notification to Building Control and should be done by a qualified electrician for safety and legal compliance.

How often should electrical installations be tested?

Domestic properties: every 10 years for owner-occupied, 5 years for rentals. Commercial properties: every 5 years, or 3 years for high-risk environments. More frequent testing may be required for older installations.

Emergency Checklist

  1. 1. Turn off main power at consumer unit
  2. 2. Do not touch electrical equipment
  3. 3. Evacuate if you smell burning
  4. 4. Call emergency electrician
  5. 5. Do not attempt repairs yourself
